statement.tex: \text{Find the area of the region in the}\\ \text{first quadrant enclosed by the x-axis,}\\ \text{the line }y=x\text{ and the circle }x^2+y^2=32.
\\ \text{What are the coordinates of }P_1\text{ - the}\\ \text{point where }y=x\text{ and the circle intersect?}
\\ \textbf{Right or wrong?} \\ \text{The required area A will equal the following.}

reason.tex: \text{The required area has to be}\\ \quad\bullet\, \text{in the first quadrant.} \\ \quad\bullet\,\text{above the x-axis.} \\ \quad\bullet\,\text{below }y = x. \\ \quad\bullet\,\text{within the circle.}

y=x\text{ and the circle will intersect when}\\ \begin{align} y &= x = \sqrt{32-x^2} \\ \implies x^2 &= 32-x^2 \text{ or } x^2 = 16 \\ \implies x &= \pm 4. \end{align} \\ \text{But as }P_1\text{ has to be in the first quadrant,}\\ \text{therefore }P_1 = (4,\sqrt{32-4^2}) = (4,4).

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Area} & \text{Range} & \text{Bounding Curve}\\ \hline A_1 & 0\to P_1 & y = x \\ \hline A_2 & P_1\to (\sqrt{32},0) & y = \sqrt{32-x^2} \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ \text{Hence, he required area will be} \\ \begin{align} A &= \int_0^4 x\cdot dx + \int_4^{\sqrt{32}}\sqrt{32-x^2}\cdot dx \end{align}

\textbf{Spot Check:}\text{Notice that }A = \dfrac{\text{circle's area}}{8} \\ = \dfrac{\pi\cdot \sqrt{32}^2}{8} = 4\pi. \\ \text{So, our answer should be }4\pi.\text{ But we have}\\ \text{to use calculus. And hence, }\\ \begin{align} &A = \int_0^4 x\cdot dx + \int_4^{\sqrt{32}}\sqrt{32-x^2}\cdot dx \\ &= \left[\dfrac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^4 + \underbrace{\left[\dfrac{1}{2}\left(x\sqrt{32-x^2}+32\tan^{-1}\dfrac{x}{\sqrt{32-x^2}}\right)\right]_4^\sqrt{32}}_ {\int\sqrt{a^2-x^2}\cdot dx = \frac{1}{2}\cdot \left(x\sqrt{a^2-x^2}+a^2\tan^{-1}\frac{x}{\sqrt{a^2-x^2}}\right)} \\ &= 8 + \dfrac{1}{2}\left[\left(0 + 32\tan^{-1}\infty\right) -\left(4\times 4 + 32\tan^{-1} 1\right)\right] \\ &=8 + \dfrac{1}{2}\left[\dfrac{32\pi}{2}-16-\dfrac{32\pi}{4}\right] = 4\pi \end{align}
